G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, as the amount in controversy does not exceed $50,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Worcester District Court under G.L. c. 223, § 2, because the tortious conduct and resulting injury occurred in Worcester County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3(a).proposition: Defendant is subject to personal jurisdiction in the Commonwealth under G.L. c. 223A, § 3(a), as she resides and conducts business within Massachusetts.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, property owners owe lawful visitors a duty to maintain their property in a reasonably safe condition and to correct or warn of dangers of which they know or reasonably should know. See Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973); Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2013).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard abolished the invitee/licensee distinction in Massachusetts and adopted a general duty of reasonable care owed by property owners to all lawful visitors, which includes maintaining premises in reasonably safe condition and warning of dangers the owner knows or should know. The provided excerpt is only a concurrence focused on trespassers, but the majority opinion in Mounsey clearly articulates the modern Massachusetts rule on duties to lawful entrants, so the case as a whole supports the proposition even though the specific quoted text does not state it directly.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: (From the Mounsey majority, not the concurrence): "We hold that the common law distinctions between licensees and invitees are abolished in this Commonwealth. The proper test of a landowner's liability to all lawful visitors is whether in the management of his property he has acted as a reasonable man in view of the probability of injury to others... The landowner must act as a reasonable man in maintaining his property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others."

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, property owners owe lawful visitors a duty to maintain their property in a reasonably safe condition and to correct or warn of dangers of which they know or reasonably should know. See Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973); Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2013).
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly restates the Massachusetts common-law duty of landowners to lawful visitors, citing Mounsey, and then applies that duty in its analysis. It confirms that owners must maintain property in a reasonably safe condition and warn of unreasonable dangers they know or should know about, while then addressing how the open and obvious doctrine and the duty to remedy interact with that baseline duty. Thus it directly supports the proposition for which it is cited.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. Id. at 743. This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973). It also includes an obligation ‘to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.’”

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of care to properly remove snow and ice from the sidewalk adjacent to her property, consistent with Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368 (2010), which abolished the natural‑accumulation rule and held that property owners must exercise reasonable care in managing snow and ice.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely abolishes the natural‑accumulation rule and holds that property owners owe lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care with respect to hazards from snow and ice, just as with other hazards. While the facts involve a mall parking lot rather than a sidewalk abutting a public way, the general rule announced applies to “all hazards arising from snow and ice” on property the defendant controls, so citing Papadopoulos for a duty to exercise reasonable care in removing snow and ice is accurate. The only caveat is that Papadopoulos does not itself alter the separate public‑way/abutting‑owner doctrine, but for on‑premises walkways it fully supports the proposition.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now abolish the distinction between natural and unnatural accumulations of snow and ice, and apply to all hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation of reasonable care that a property owner owes to lawful visitors regarding all other hazards… If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825 (19.proposition: Defendant breached this duty by failing to take reasonable steps—such as properly clearing ice, applying salt or sand, or warning invitees—after she knew or should have known of the hazardous condition. See Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825 (1994); Barry v. Beverley Enterprises–Mass., Inc., 418 Mass. 590 (1994).
Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825 (19.support_reasoning: Sullivan holds that a landowner does not breach the duty of reasonable care by failing to remove, sand, or otherwise treat a natural accumulation of snow and ice, absent some act that changes the snow/ice from its natural condition. The court explicitly rejects liability based on the town’s failure to sand or remove the ice on the ramp, characterizing the condition as a nonactionable natural accumulation. Thus, Sullivan does not support the proposition that a defendant breaches its duty by failing to clear or treat ice after knowing of the hazard; it stands for the opposite, within the natural‑accumulation framework then applicable in Massachusetts.
Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825 (19.relevant_excerpt: “In our most recent decision addressing an owner’s duty with regard to snow and ice, we made clear that this duty is not violated by a failure to remove a natural accumulation of snow or ice. Aylward v. McCloskey, 412 Mass. 77, 80 (1992)… Liability is possible only ‘in circumstances where some act or failure to act has changed the condition of naturally accumulated snow and ice….’ … [T]he evidence indicates only that the ice on which the plaintiff fell was a natural accumulation…. [T]here can be no liability because… ‘naturally accumulated snow and ice on property does not per se constitute a defective condition.’”

Barry v. Beverley Enterprises\u2013Mass..raw_text: Barry v. Beverley Enterprises–Mass., Inc., 418 Mass. 590 (1994)
Barry v. Beverley Enterprises\u2013Mass..proposition: Defendant breached this duty by failing to take reasonable steps—such as properly clearing ice, applying salt or sand, or warning invitees—after she knew or should have known of the hazardous condition. See Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825 (1994); Barry v. Beverley Enterprises–Mass., Inc., 418 Mass. 590 (1994).
Barry v. Beverley Enterprises\u2013Mass..support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that the defendant breached its duty by failing to take reasonable remedial steps (clear ice, apply salt/sand, or warn) after it knew or should have known of the hazardous condition. Barry, however, holds that the evidence was insufficient to show the defendant knew or should have known of the icy condition, and therefore concludes there was no breach for failing to remove the ice or warn. The case describes the duty conceptually but ultimately finds no violation on these facts, so it does not affirmatively support the proposition of breach; it is more appropriately cited as a limitation on liability absent notice.
Barry v. Beverley Enterprises\u2013Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Thus, a defendant who did not have a reasonable opportunity to discover and remedy a hazardous condition — that is, a defendant who had no actual or constructive knowledge of the allegedly hazardous condition so that it could not reasonably remove, or warn the plaintiff of, the danger — cannot be found to have violated its duty of care. … In sum, the jury could not reasonably have inferred that the defendant violated its duty of reasonable care by failing to remove the ice or to warn the plaintiff of a potential hazard.”

O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201 (.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constituted negligence under Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343, adopted in Massachusetts. See O’Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201 (2000).
O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201 (.support_reasoning: The opinion does not apply Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 or adopt it; instead it applies Massachusetts’ common-law premises liability and the open and obvious danger doctrine to hold that the defendants owed no duty and thus were not negligent. The court’s analysis is framed entirely in terms of duty and the ‘open and obvious’ rule, not § 343, and the ultimate holding rejects liability rather than finding the defendant’s conduct negligent under § 343. Accordingly, this case does not support a proposition that the defendant’s conduct constituted negligence under § 343 as adopted in Massachusetts.
O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201 (.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises… However, a landowner’s duty to protect lawful visitors against dangerous conditions on his property ordinarily does not extend to dangers that would be obvious to persons of average intelligence… we conclude that the Legislature’s express abolition of ‘the defense of assumption of risk’ … leaves intact the open and obvious danger rule, which operates to negate the existence of a duty of care… We conclude that… the defendants had no duty to warn the plaintiff… and, therefore, they could not be found liable for his injuries.”

Aylward v. McCloskey, 412 Mass. 77 (1992.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes liability on a property owner where she causes or permits an accumulation of snow and ice that presents an unreasonable risk of harm. See Papadopoulos, supra; Aylward v. McCloskey, 412 Mass. 77 (1992).
Aylward v. McCloskey, 412 Mass. 77 (1992.support_reasoning: The proposition reflects the post-Papadopoulos rule eliminating the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and imposing a general duty of reasonable care as to snow and ice. Aylward, however, applies the pre-Papadopoulos rule and expressly holds that a landowner is not liable for injuries caused by a mere natural accumulation of snow and ice absent some additional defect or owner-caused condition. Thus, Aylward does not support, and in fact contradicts, the proposition that Massachusetts law imposes liability whenever an owner causes or permits an unreasonable snow-and-ice risk.
Aylward v. McCloskey, 412 Mass. 77 (1992.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs wrongly conclude, however, that the defendants breached this duty by failing to remove a natural accumulation of snow and ice on their property… Significantly… this court stated that the simple fact that a person slips on ice on another’s property does not subject the property owner to liability… There is no evidence in this case which would allow a jury to find that the defendants failed to exercise reasonable care in the circumstances and created a defective condition on their property.”

Jette v. Boston, 428 Mass. 536 (1998).proposition: Defendant’s failure to act after receiving notice of the dangerous ice condition demonstrates reckless disregard for the safety of lawful entrants, in violation of the duty established in Jette v. Boston, 428 Mass. 536 (1998).
Jette v. Boston, 428 Mass. 536 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion in Jette v. Boston does not address premises liability, dangerous ice conditions, or a defendant’s reckless disregard for the safety of lawful entrants. Instead, it concerns juvenile care-and-protection proceedings and the statutory and due process rights to temporary custody hearings under G.L. c. 119, §§ 24 and 25. Citing this case for a duty regarding dangerous ice conditions is therefore inaccurate and unrelated to the holding or reasoning of the opinion.
Jette v. Boston, 428 Mass. 536 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Whenever a child’s legal custodian is to be changed pursuant to G. L. c. 119, § 24, as occurred here, the parties, including the child, have the right to be heard and to have the judge consider their nominations of possible legal custodians for the child.… We have held that protection of the parties’ due process rights is of great importance at a seventy-two hour hearing.”

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries were foreseeable and directly caused by Defendant’s negligence, as defined in Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 and recognized in Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion cites Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 only for the general elements of negligence and then holds that plaintiffs failed to prove causation, because the collapse of the scaffolding was unexplained and any link to defendant’s conduct was speculative. The court does not find that plaintiffs’ injuries were foreseeably and directly caused by defendant’s negligence; instead, it affirms summary judgment precisely because causation was not established. Thus, the case undermines rather than supports the proposition that the plaintiff’s injuries were foreseeably and directly caused by the defendant’s negligence under § 281.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965)… The record reflects that the plaintiffs failed to proffer any evidence explaining why the scaffold collapsed and therefore cannot establish any causal link between their injuries and the defendant’s breach of any duty to them….”

Cannon v. Carroll, 324 Mass. 343 (1949).proposition: Plaintiff suffered personal injuries, medical expenses, wage loss, and pain and suffering as a proximate result of Defendant’s negligent acts and omissions. See Cannon v. Carroll, 324 Mass. 343 (1949); Fidler v. E.M. Parker Co., 394 Mass. 534 (1985).
Cannon v. Carroll, 324 Mass. 343 (1949).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the validity of a Nevada divorce decree and whether the Massachusetts court may reexamine jurisdictional facts in an ex parte foreign divorce, plus whether certain conduct constitutes cruel and abusive treatment for purposes of divorce. It does not address personal injury damages, proximate cause, medical expenses, wage loss, or pain and suffering resulting from negligent acts or omissions. Therefore, citing this case for that tort-damages proposition is inaccurate.
Cannon v. Carroll, 324 Mass. 343 (1949).relevant_excerpt: We need not recount the reported evidence, as the libellee does not contend that there was no evidence of three instances of physical violence reported by the judge. In the summer of 1933 when they were returning from New York by automobile the libellee hit the libellant with a pillow; her head fell back; she became hysterical; and the libellee threatened to leave her on the road. Early in December, 1933, he became angry, swore at her, called her vile names, pushed her, and went away.

Fidler v. E.M. Parker Co., 394 Mass. 534.raw_text: Fidler v. E.M. Parker Co., 394 Mass. 534 (1985)
Fidler v. E.M. Parker Co., 394 Mass. 534.proposition: Plaintiff suffered personal injuries, medical expenses, wage loss, and pain and suffering as a proximate result of Defendant’s negligent acts and omissions. See Cannon v. Carroll, 324 Mass. 343 (1949); Fidler v. E.M. Parker Co., 394 Mass. 534 (1985).
Fidler v. E.M. Parker Co., 394 Mass. 534.case_name: Fidler v. E. M. Parker Co.
Fidler v. E.M. Parker Co., 394 Mass. 534.support_reasoning: The opinion in Fidler v. E.M. Parker Co. addresses statutes of limitation and collateral estoppel in a products liability case; it does not discuss or establish the general tort principle that a plaintiff suffered personal injuries, medical expenses, wage loss, and pain and suffering as a proximate result of a defendant’s negligence. The court assumes injuries for purposes of the limitations analysis but never analyzes proximate cause, nor does it set out any rule about the elements or measure of such damages. Thus, it does not meaningfully support the stated proposition, which concerns causation and damages rather than limitations or preclusion.
Fidler v. E.M. Parker Co., 394 Mass. 534.relevant_excerpt: "Deborah Fidler seeks damages for negligence and breach of express and implied warranties for injuries allegedly caused by Pantopaque contrast medium. She claims that, as a result of the use of Pantopaque in the course of three myelograms, she suffered injury, including severe head, face, and eye pain. Her husband, Donald Fidler, seeks damages for loss of consortium."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B, Plaintiff seeks prejudgment interest from the date of commencement of this action.

G.L. c. 261, \u00a7 1.proposition: Costs of suit, including filing fees and service expenses pursuant to G.L. c. 261, § 1;
